[[div class="report-box"]]
+++ PAGE COMMENTARY (ARCHIVED)
++++ Last updated: June 2018.
----
[[span style="font-weight: bold"]]Flops Says:[[/span]] This commentary covers only one-fifth of my written work on the Wiki. I won't update this again, if only because there's too much work to make commentary on, and I would rather let my work speak for itself.

If you're curious, I do include some writing/background information in the author posts for all my individual works.
[[/div]]

[[div class="blockquote solid"]]
+++ --SCP-2641: Before the Fire-- **[DELETED]**
+++ URA-2641 and [[[solidao|Solid√£o]]]
----
[[collapsible show="Learn more?" hide="Close" hideLocation="bottom"]]
**Summary:** SCP-2641 was an ancient sapient concept that lived inside literary media.

Persons exposed to affected media became a physical conduit connecting 2641 with the outside world. 2641 made objects act tangentially to the way they're meant to, and in a surreal manner. Each time, it spread into a new medium; each time, it gained power. After 2641 connected with enough objects, media, and people, it regained its lost reality-bending properties.

This SCP featured:
* A dense rainforest.
* A mysterious cult contained by the Brazilian government.
* Exploding spears.
* A father wishing to save his daughter.
* An exiled and disillusioned denizen from Plato's World of Forms.
----
**Commentary:** SCP-2641 was my 1st SCP, written in April 2017 after the SCP-3000 "Horror" Contest.

2641 was an experiment. I wanted to write an SCP that was contained within its own documentation. I wanted to justify why the Foundation would even do such a thing. And I wanted to show that there was something very wrong happening behind the scenes. I wasn't the most successful in executing these three things, but at the time, I was happy with how everything turned out.

The idea began with, "what if objects acted the //opposite// of how they're supposed to?" It took a lot of writing and rewriting to make that idea make sense.
----
**Themes:** Brazilian governmental politics; isolation; revenge.
----
**UPDATE:** I self-deleted this page in mid-2018. I was unhappy with its performance over its lifetime on the site (just over a year), and I didn't think I was a good enough author to execute it yet.

Though the concept had been dropped, I still consider its existence a part of my Authorial Canon.

If you still wish to read this story, it exists in a different format without all the filler:

* [[[solidao|Solid√£o]]]
[[/collapsible]]
[[/div]]

[[div class="blockquote solid"]]
+++ [[[scp-3787|SCP-3787: The Horse Meme]]]
----
[[collapsible show="Learn more?" hide="Close" hideLocation="bottom"]]
**Summary:** A mysterious group of antimemetic equine entities is trying to give themselves some power on Earth. To counteract this, in what is perhaps the failed //Deus ex Machina// of a drowsy god, horses begin breeding 10 times more quickly. The size of equine concepts in the collective human headspace increases dramatically, and humans become very afraid. This increase in "conceptual horseness", however, is effective in scaring away the entities -- who fear the more powerful common Horse.

Of course, the Foundation tries to contain this strange horse anomaly by slowing down horse birth rates. Not only do they start a mass horse die-off, but the entities pour into our world to wreak havoc throughout North America.

This page has many things packed into it -- such as an explanation for where modern-day mnestics come from, and the SCP-2000 of horses. It also features Mobile Task Force Pi-5 ("Glue Factory"), which battles antimemetic horse people with laser weapons, and is frankly //the coolest gosh darn thing ever.//
----
**Commentary:** SCP-3787 was my 2nd SCP, written in February 2018.

It took an awfully long time to come up with a second SCP. 3787 was far more ambitious than 2641, and I pitched it by referring to it as "the 001 of horse anomalies". Like with 2641, I was unhappy with the way I executed things. This time, however, I later went back and cleaned it up.
----
**Themes:** The dangers of creeping nationalism; nyctophobia; the Foundation at war.
[[/collapsible]]
[[/div]]

[[div class="blockquote solid"]]
+++ [[[scp-3719|SCP-3719: Your Friendly Neighbourhood Lawnmower]]]
----
[[collapsible show="Learn more?" hide="Close" hideLocation="bottom"]]
**Summary:** It's a lawnmower. Somehow, it ended up in a Baltimore suburb, quickly making the neighbourhood closer than it's ever been -- by fusing a bunch of residents into a 5,000-kg flesh ball that mows lawns perpetually. //And they enjoy it.//
----
**Commentary:** SCP-3719 was my 3rd SCP, written in March 2018.

I haven't much to talk about in terms of how I wrote it because, to be honest, only a few days passed between when I started and when I posted. I wanted to write something like this for about a year before I actually posted it, but couldn't figure out how.
----
**Themes:** Tragedies in the news; body horror; community bonds.
[[/collapsible]]
[[/div]]

[[div class="blockquote solid"]]
+++ [[[scp-3309|SCP-3309: Where We Go When We Fade, Fade Away]]]
----
[[collapsible show="Learn more?" hide="Close" hideLocation="bottom"]]
**Summary:** The Foundation classifies coldposts as a legitimate in-universe concept. When they learn they can //delete// these coldposts -- as Wiki staff must do to their out-of-universe counterparts -- they do so with extreme prejudice and imprecision. This causes everything to go wrong.
----
**Commentary:** SCP-3309 was my 4th SCP and 1st collab, co-written with [[user PhamtomGuy]] in April 2018. This was both my 1st format screw and 1st attempt at a meta article.

3309 is a bit of a strange one for me. I'm not exactly a fan of meta articles myself unless they're written competently. And I don't actually think the work I put into 3309 is enough to consider it a well-done meta article. 3309 is an ambitious story -- and ambitious stories call for ambitious writing. I do believe I put in decent writing, but not enough to allow for all its parts to flow smoothly. Suffice to say: I don't think there's enough here for me to be satisfied about, but it's difficult to point out what exactly is the issue. Maybe the concept needs work; maybe it relies too much on a gimmick; maybe both.

Of course, as a collaborative page, there comes a point when both parties must agree to take the middle path and be happy with the work they've put in. To my co-writer, it may seem that we kept this page on the burner for long enough and that it needed to be posted, and the votes certainly seem to display a job well done. But there will always be something in me that isn't happy with the work I put in, and I guess that might never change.

Altogether, 3309 was a learning experience, and I hope I'm able to continue progressing as a writer.

(**NOTE:** I don't necessarily believe that votes = a decent work. 3309 was controversial -- especially among site contributors -- but ended up doing incredibly well).
----
**Themes:** Depression & anxiety; the fear of being forgotten; the plight of the tortured character.
----

[[div class="blockquote solid"]]
+++ [[[scp-3464|SCP-3464: Olive Garden regularly communes with DEMONIC ENTITIES to summon their SATANIC sempiternal garlic bread]]]
----
[[collapsible show="Learn more?" hide="Close" hideLocation="bottom"]]
**Summary:** Some wizardy assholes steal Mr. Krab's secret garlic bread formula and start summoning demons with it.
----
**Commentary:** SCP-3464 was my 5th SCP, written in May 2018.

Five years ago, I wrote an extremely gross creepypasta about an ever-growing garlic bread, and a person who had to eat their way through it. The strange shenanigans involved with such a phenomenon were my inspiration here. So, the plan was to make it a relatively inane anart project used to spread the word about food waste. That's a pretty important thing, but it's probably at the //bottom// of the Foundation's list of things to worry about when the universe could spontaneously turn into cheese.

What other aspects are at place? There's the ghostly voice of Don LaFontaine; a Foundation thaumaturge (because they have those too); demonic shenanigans inspired heavily by Third Law; and an actual demon possessing a hunk of garlic bread.

This one's a fun romp altogether -- promise!
----
**Themes:** Sabotage; demons; wizard chefs.
[[/collapsible]]
[[/div]]

[[div class="blockquote solid"]]
+++ [[[spc-507|SPC-507: The Bigger Boat]]]
----
[[collapsible show="Learn more?" hide="Close" hideLocation="bottom"]]
**Summary:** The Shark Punching Centre discovers Selachian threats from beyond their universe and puts together a Marine Fighting Team with the know-how to punch them.
----
**Commentary:** SPC-507 was my 1st GOI Format, written in May 2018, and my 1st entry in the 2018 Doomsday Contest.

One thing I wasn't too happy about was the page's density, which people had rightfully criticized at the time. After receiving a large amount of critique and spending time rewriting significant portions of this, I'm now proud to say it: This should be an enjoyable read!

Either way, this was my attempt at giving the Centre a reason to exist in the main Foundation Universe. It also gives the Avian Division more power to fight that devious Thoth!
----
**Other:**

||~ MFT "CHARYBDIS" and "SCYLLA" || References to Greek mythology. ||
||~ "FASH" || A "bash the fash**@@*@@**" joke. ||
||~ "G√¶gr" and "Kemdulnim" || Generated with a fantasy dragon name generator. ||
||~ "Quibba" and "Keshrayuth" || Generated with a bird race name generator. ||
||~ Kaa, Waxaklahun, and Mih || Mayan numbers. ||
||~ "LIMP FIREBIRD" || A self-insert. ;) ||
|||| ***NOTE:** Those depth-damned Sharkicist bastards. ||

For Marine Fighting Team CHARYBDIS, I chose names that are conventionally gender neutral.

* "Quinn" and "Jaedan" are male characters.
* "Leah" and "Haruki" are female characters.

The SPC universe deviated from the main Foundation Universe a few thousand years ago. As such, this page features some alternative history elements. Here are some examples:
||~ The Kingdom of Mycenae || Greece ||
||~ Poseidon Labs || Prometheus Labs ||
||~ Bee Obliteration Registry "K" || Directorate K. Coined by PortalHunter from {{#site19}}. ||
||~ Seventh Deviant Crusade || Seventh Occult War ||
----
**Themes:** Universe-hopping shenanigans; absurdity; teamwork.

[[module CSS]]
/* == SITE BANNER == */

 :root {
	--header-subtitle: "NO VEIL CAN HOLD THE HEAVENS";

	--accentColor: hsl(180, 60%, 50%);
	--accentColorLite: hsla(180, 60%, 60%, .5);
	--hue: 180deg;

	--bgColor: hsl(220, 59%, 27%);
	--mgColor: hsl(220, 22%, 9%);
	--fgColor: hsl(220, 60%, 15%);

	--borderColor: var(--accentColor);
	--bgBadgeColor: var(--fgColor);
}

 body {
	background-image:
	   linear-gradient(
		var(--mgColor) 0 180px,
		var(--bgColor) 720px 100%);
}

 @media (min-width: 768px) {
	 #main-content {
		max-width: 80%;
	}
}

 :where(h1, h2, h3, h4, h5) {
	color: var(--textColorMid);
}

 .lite-heading.extra-wide {
	position: relative;
	left: calc(-33vw + 50%);
	width: 66vw;
	max-width: 66vw;

	background:
	   linear-gradient(
		to right,
		transparent,
		var(--fgColor) 10% 90%,
		transparent);
}

 @media (max-width: 767px) {
	 .lite-heading.extra-wide {
		left: unset;
		width: unset;
		max-width: unset;
	}
}

 .lite-heading.extra-wide hr {
	height: .3rem;

	background:
	   linear-gradient(
		to right,
		transparent,
		var(--accentColor) 10% 90%,
		transparent);
	border: 0;
}

 .lite-heading.extra-wide h1 {
	font-size: 2.95rem;
}

/* == BOOKSHELF == */

 div.bookshelf {
	display: flex;
	flex-flow: wrap;
}

 div.book {
	display: flex;
	flex: 50%;
	flex-direction: column;
	align-items: center;
	justify-content: center;
	height: 6rem;
}

 @media (max-width: 768px) {
	 div.book {
		flex: 100%;
	}
}

 div.book p {
	margin: 0;
}

/* == TABS == */

 .yui-navset .yui-content {
	padding-top: 2rem;

	background: hsla(220, 60%, 21%);
}

 .yui-navset .yui-nav .selected a,
 .yui-navset .yui-nav .selected a:active,
 .yui-navset .yui-nav .selected a:focus {
	color: var(--keyColor);
}

 .translations .collapsible-block-link::before,
 .translations .collapsible-block-link::after,
 .translations .collapsible-block-unfolded .collapsible-block-link::before,
 .translations .collapsible-block-unfolded .collapsible-block-link::after {
	content: "";
}

/* == MEGA COOL AUTHOR PAGE TOOL == */

 .content-box {
	margin-bottom: 1rem !important;
}

 .content-box:hover {
	box-shadow:
		0 .53rem var(--fgColor),
		0 -.27rem var(--fgColor) !important;
}

 .content-box .content-section .translations iframe.scpnet-interwiki-frame,
 .content-box .content-section .translations div.scpnet-interwiki-wrapper {
	height: 290px !important;
}

 .top-border {
	border-color: var(--textColorAlt) !important;
}

 #page-content .tooltip > a[href*="dark-achievement-badges"] {
	border-bottom: 0;
}

/* == FLOPSTYLE: DARK MODS == */

 .image-box {
	border: 0 !important;
}

 .blockquote.artpreciation > p {
	margin-top: -.4rem;
}

 @media (min-width: 768px) {
	 .blockquote.lightweight.exhibit p,
	 .blockquote.lightweight.exhibit ul {
		margin: .4rem 0;
	}

	 .blockquote.lightweight.exhibit h4 {
		color: var(--textColorMid);
	}

	 .blockquote.lightweight.exhibit {
		width: 500px;
		min-height: 240px;
	}
}

/* == CURRICULUM VITAE == */

 .cv {
	--accentColor: hsl(360, 71%, 70%);
	--accentColorLite: hsla(360, 71%, 80%, .5);
}

 .cv h1 {
	--accentColor: hsl(360, 70%, 70%);
}

 .cv h5 {
	justify-content: start;
}

 .cv a {
	font-weight: bold;
}

 .cv strong {
	color: var(--textColorMid);
	font-size: .9rem;
}

 .cv strong::after {
	content: " ¬ª";
	padding: 0 .2rem;
}

 .cv .library {
	--accentColor: hsl(46, 79%, 50%);
	--accentColorLite: hsla(46, 79%, 60%, .5);
}

 .cv .declassification {
	--accentColor: hsl(270, 60%, 60%);
	--accentColorLite: hsla(270, 60%, 70%, .5);
}

 .cv .translator,
 .cv .editor {
	padding: .02rem .2rem;

	background: var(--accentColorTrans);
}

 .cv .translator {
	--accentColor: hsl(135, 55%, 55%);
	--accentColorLite: hsla(135, 55%, 65%, .5);
	--accentColorTrans: hsla(135, 55%, 55%, .1);
}

 .cv .editor {
	--accentColor: hsl(225, 65%, 65%);
	--accentColorLite: hsla(225, 75%, 75%, .5);
	--accentColorTrans: hsla(225, 65%, 65%, .1);
}

 .idle {
	opacity: .65;
}

 .moo {
	color: hsl(214, 70%, 65%);

	font-weight: bold;
}

 .lie {
	--accentColor: var(--textColorHigh);
	--accentColorLite: var(--textColorIdle);
	padding: 1px 3px;

	background: hsla(207, 75%, 50%, .3);

	font: bold .95rem/1.5 var(--mono-font);
	word-break: normal;
}

 .FL_parent {
	display: flex;
	align-items: center;
	justify-content: space-around;
}

 .FL_child {
	width: fit-content;
	margin: auto;

	font-size: .85rem;
}

/* == DIVS == */

 .blockquote {
	margin-right: 0;
	margin-left: 0;
}

 .blockquote .blockquote {
	margin-right: 1rem;
	margin-left: 1rem;

	border-left-width: medium;
}

/* == X-SMALL BREAKPOINT == */

 @media (max-width: 575.9px) {
	 #header h1 a { font-size: calc(.75em + 3.5vw); }
	 #header h2 { font-size: calc(.75em + 1.75vw); }
}

/* == SMALL BREAKPOINT == */

 @media (min-width: 576px) and (max-width: 767.9px) {
	 #header h1 a { font-size: calc(.75em + 3vw); }
	 #header h2 { font-size: calc(.75em + 1.5vw); }
}

 @media (max-width: 767.9px) {
	 #header h2 { margin-top: .5em; }
}

/* == MEDIUM BREAKPOINT == */

 @media (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 983.9px) {
	 #header h1 a { font-size: calc(.75em + 2.5vw); }
	 #header h2 { margin-top: 0; font-size: calc(.75em + 1.25vw); }
}

/* == LARGE BREAKPOINT == */

 @media (min-width: 984px) and (max-width: 1199.9px) {
	 #header h1 a { font-size: calc(.75em + 2vw); }
	 #header h2 { font-size: calc(.75em + 1vw); }
	 #header h1 a::before { font-size: unset; }
	 #header h2::before { font-size: unset; }
}
[[/module]]
author: Lt Flops
